turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Storm's getting worse.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: "A perfect night for mystery and horror.  The air itself is filled with monsters."

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: That's from your movie, right? "The only monsters are here."

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: I don't remember that one.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: James Whale.  This afternoon at the party.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: I said it must be weird seeing your monsters again, and you said, "The only monsters are here."  I was wondering which here you meant.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: I don't recall.  Memories of the war, perhaps.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: But that was so long ago.  It can't still bother you.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Oh, but it does.  Especially in light of the journey I'm about to make.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: You're planning a trip?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Barnett.  Barnett on the wire.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Your friend?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Oh death where is thy sting-a-ling? Grave where thy victory?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: You survived it.  It can't hurt you now.  It's no good to dig it up.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Oh no, my friend.  It's digging itself up.  There is nothing in the here and now to take my mind off it.  All my diversions have abandoned me.  Parties.  Reading. Painting.  Work.  Love.  All gone to me now.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: So it is going to happen after all.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: What'd you say?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: No.  It won't do.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: What won't do?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: You are much too human.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: What did you expect?  Bronze?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Don't move.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: For the artistic effect.  The combination of your human body and that inhuman mask.  It's quite striking.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Please, Clayton.  Just for a minute.  Long enough for me to see the effect.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: It's from the first World War, isn't it?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: There are straps in back.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: All right.  Let's take it off now.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: What was that?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: It's too tight.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Just take off the fucking mask!

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Relax, Clayton.  I can't hear you. I can't hear a word.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: I'm not that way.  Get it through your fucking head.  I don't want to mess with you.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Oh, but you feel good, Clayton.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Wait until I tell my friends I had you naked in my arms.  Won't they be surprised?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: I haven't done a damn thing with you!

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Oh, but you have.  You undressed for me.  I kissed you.  I even touched your prick.  How will you be able to live with yourself?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Break my neck.  Or strangle me.  It would be oh so easy to wrap your hands around my neck and choke the life out of me.  Please, Clayton. We've come this far.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: You're crazy.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Look, if you want to die do it yourself!

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: No, I don't want to die alone.  But to be killed by you -- that would make death bearable.  They say you never see the one with your name on it.  But I want to see death coming at me.  I want it to be sharp and hard, with a human face.  Your face.  Think, Clayton.  You'd be my second Monster.  Almost as famous as the first.  It would be the great adventure you've yearned for. A war story for both of us to share.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: You okay?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Oh Clayton.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Did I hurt you?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Nothing I didn't deserve.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Need some help?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Pray you, undo this button.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: I can undress myself, thank you.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: All right.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: When you die...be sure your brain is the last organ to fizzle --

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: You'll feel better tomorrow.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Tomorrow and tomorrow and tomorrow...

turns.speaker: DWIGHT
turns.text: Boone!  You awake?  Eight o'clock.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Fuck off!

turns.speaker: DWIGHT
turns.text: You told me to get you up, asshole.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: I'm up.  Thanks.

turns.speaker: DWIGHT
turns.text: Hasta la vista, Boone.  And give the jail bait a squeeze for me.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: I liked it.  You learn stuff listening to old-timers.

turns.speaker: DWIGHT
turns.text: You ever hear of this Whale fellow?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: This kisser wasn't so bad you couldn't lay under it a few times.

turns.speaker: DWIGHT
turns.text: Ooooh.

turns.speaker: DWIGHT
turns.text: You coming, Boone?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: I think I'll hang around.

turns.speaker: DWIGHT
turns.text: Hey, Boone.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Have a drink?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Can't say that I have.  Can't say I've heard of a lot of people though.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: If you don't believe me, let's watch this movie.  See if his name's on it.  How about it, Harry? Can I watch my damn movie?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: I told you.  I don't turn on the TV except for the fights.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Calm down, Clay.  Just calm down. We'll watch it.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Good.  Fine.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: You're like a dog with a bone over this movie, Clay.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: I just want to watch it, okay?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Sick stuff.  Necrophilia.  I wonder if they knew how sick they were.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: The Monster's lonely and he wants a friend, a girlfriend, somebody. What sick about that?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Go home, Clay.  We're closing up.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: I thought I'd give you a hand since I kept you open.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Where's Betty?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: She took the night off.  Heavy date.  Some guy she's had her eye on for a while.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: She tells me you haven't been sleeping well.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: It's the ridiculous pills they prescribe.  If I take them, I spend the next day stupid as a stone. If I don't, my mind seems to go off in a hundred directions at once --

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Then take the pills.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: I wanted to be alert for your visit today.  Especially since I saw so little of you in the hospital.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: I'm sorry, Jimmy.  But with this movie and two difficult stars --

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: "The fault, dear David, is not in ourselves but in our stars."

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: You remember how a production eats up one's life.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Oh, David.  There's no pleasure in making you feel guilty.  You better go, my boy.  You'll be late for that aeroplane.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: By the way, I like the Renoir.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Goodbye, Hanna.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: What are you doing here?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Just what I was about to ask you. I thought you were in New York.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: I was, until last night.  Publicity asked me to fly Miss Taylor in for today's reception.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Should you be drinking in your condition?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Oh, David, stop being a nanny.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: You should have seen Georgie's face when he met Clayton.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: You didn't, Jimmy.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: I did.  But Princess Margaret was a doll.  We're all equals in her eyes.  As commoners, I presume.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: You only embarrass yourself.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Oh dear.  I'll never work in this town again?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: You know what I mean.  Your reputation.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: But I have no reputation.  I'm as free as the air.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Well the rest of us aren't.  Can't you remember that?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: No.  I never could.  You must regret having had the invitation sent.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: I didn't ask George to invite you.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Then who did?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Jimmy, there are people here I need to speak to.  You'll be fine on your own?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Yes.  Perfectly.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: All right, then.  I'll come by tomorrow for breakfast.

turns.speaker: DR. PAYNE
turns.text: You're a lucky man, Mr. Whale. Whatever damage was done by your stroke, it left your motor abilities relatively unimpaired.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Yes, yes, Dr. Payne.  But from the neck up?  What's my story there?

turns.speaker: DR. PAYNE
turns.text: That's what I'm trying to explain.

turns.speaker: DR. PAYNE
turns.text: The central nervous system selects items from a constant storm of sensations.  Whatever was killed in your stroke appears to have short-circuited this mechanism. Parts of your brain now seem to be firing at random.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: You're saying there's an electrical storm in my head?

turns.speaker: DR. PAYNE
turns.text: That's as good a way as any to describe it.  I've seen far worse cases.  You might even learn to enjoy these walks down memory lane.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: But the rest of it?  The killing headaches.  The phantom smells.  My inability to close my eyes without thinking a hundred things at once. It's all nothing more than bad electricity?

turns.speaker: DR. PAYNE
turns.text: In a manner of speaking.  I've never encountered the olfactory hallucinations, but I'm sure they're related.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: So what do I do?

turns.speaker: DR. PAYNE
turns.text: Take the Luminal to sleep, or whenever you feel an attack coming on.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: You seem to be saying that this isn't just a case of resting until I'm better.  That my condition will continue to deteriorate until the end of my life.

turns.speaker: ERNEST THESIGER
turns.text: My God.  Is the audience to presume that Colin and I have done her hair?  I thought we were mad scientists, not hairdressers.

turns.speaker: ELSA LANCHESTER
turns.text: Only a mad scientist could do this to a woman.

turns.speaker: ERNEST THESIGER
turns.text: Oh no, my dear.  You look absolutely amazing.  There's no way I can compete with you.  The scene is yours.

turns.speaker: ELSA LANCHESTER
turns.text: In the sequel, James, two lady scientists should make a monster. And our monster would be Gary Cooper.

turns.speaker: ERNEST THESIGER
turns.text: I would've thought Mr. Leslie Howard would be more your line.

turns.speaker: ELSA LANCHESTER
turns.text: More your line.

turns.speaker: ERNEST THESIGER
turns.text: My line nowadays runs to Rin Tin Tin.  Dogs are so much more dependable than men.

turns.speaker: ELSA LANCHESTER
turns.text: Uh-oh.  The way you look at me, James.  What have you done this time?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Bring a mirror.  Let the Bride feast upon her visage.

turns.speaker: ELSA LANCHESTER
turns.text: Boris?  Do I look a fright?

turns.speaker: ELSA LANCHESTER
turns.text: And you said there'd be some of me left.  Nobody's going to know me in this getup.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Nonsense, my dear.  You look extraordinary.  Today's script.  Quick.  And a pencil.

turns.speaker: ELSA LANCHESTER
turns.text: Jimmy.  How are you?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Elsa?

turns.speaker: ELSA LANCHESTER
turns.text: I saw Una O'Conner a few weeks ago. She said you'd been under the weather.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Oh, nothing out of the ordinary. Growing old.

turns.speaker: ELSA LANCHESTER
turns.text: We're all getting a bit long in the tooth.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: But you appear quite fresh, my dear.

turns.speaker: ELSA LANCHESTER
turns.text: Please.  You shouldn't stand on my account.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Perfectly all right.  But if you'd like to sit --

turns.speaker: ELSA LANCHESTER
turns.text: I'm fine, Jimmy.  I can only stay a few minutes.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Of course.

turns.speaker: ELSA LANCHESTER
turns.text: What's our pesky friend up to now?

turns.speaker: ELSA LANCHESTER
turns.text: Is that Boris?  Our little chum appears to be arranging a reunion.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Oh dear.

turns.speaker: ELSA LANCHESTER
turns.text: We'll be in touch, Jimmy.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Good-bye.  So nice to see you...

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Hanna?  Who's the new yardman?

turns.speaker: HANNA
turns.text: Bone?  Boom?  Something Bee.  I hire him while you were in the hospital.  He came cheap.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: There is iced tea, Hanna?  Cucumber sandwiches?

turns.speaker: HANNA
turns.text: Yes, Mr. Jimmy.  An interview.  After so many years. Very exciting.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Don't be daft.  It's just a student from the university.

turns.speaker: HANNA
turns.text: Mr. Kay, sir.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: HANNA
turns.text: Which ones?  I bring them all.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Luminal.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: You must think I'm terrible, Hanna.

turns.speaker: HANNA
turns.text: I do not think you anything anymore.  Just back from the hospital and already you are chasing after boys.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Oh shut up.  All we did was talk. My attack had nothing to do with him.

turns.speaker: HANNA
turns.text: Perhaps we should get you uphill before the pills knock you cold.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: No.  Let me lie here.  Thank you.

turns.speaker: HANNA
turns.text: How are you feeling, Mr. Jimmy? How is your mind today?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: My mind's lovely.  And yours?

turns.speaker: HANNA
turns.text: You remember what the doctor tells us.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Yes, yes, yes.  I merely invited Mr. Boone in for a glass of tea. We'll have a brief chat and he'll finish the yard.

turns.speaker: HANNA
turns.text: I am not forgetting your last brief chat.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Just go.  We can manage without you.

turns.speaker: HANNA
turns.text: He looks plenty big.  You won't need my help if anything goes flooey.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Go.

turns.speaker: HANNA
turns.text: Oh, that monster.  How could you be working with him?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Don't be silly, Hanna.  He's a very proper actor.  And the dullest fellow imaginable.

turns.speaker: HANNA
turns.text: He is not going to kill the old man?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: No, Hanna.  My heart isn't that black.

turns.speaker: HANNA
turns.text: She is horrible.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: She is beautiful.

turns.speaker: HANNA
turns.text: You will take them all, Mr. Jimmy?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: I'll be fine, Hanna.  Thank you.

turns.speaker: HANNA
turns.text: Good night.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Does the yardman come today?

turns.speaker: HANNA
turns.text: Of course.  This afternoon.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Who was that at the door?

turns.speaker: HANNA
turns.text: A visitor.

turns.speaker: HANNA
turns.text: Mr. Boone.  He is an interesting friend.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: I'd hardly call our yardman a friend.

turns.speaker: HANNA
turns.text: No.  But someone you can talk to.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Do you miss having someone to talk to, Hanna?

turns.speaker: HANNA
turns.text: I have my family.  Also our Lord Jesus Christ.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Of course.  How is the old boy these days?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: It needs a hat.  There was a wide-brimmed cream fedora...

turns.speaker: HANNA
turns.text: It must be up in your old room.  I will look.

turns.speaker: HANNA
turns.text: That is my daughter.  She say she and her husband are coming to town this afternoon.  I am sorry, Mr. Jimmy.  I will make it short.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: I'll be out this afternoon, remember?  Your family can visit as long as they like.

turns.speaker: HANNA
turns.text: No.  I do not cook for them.  My daughter's no-good husband will not take one bite of our food.

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: Mr. Whale, this is such an honor. You're one of my favorite all-time directors.  I can't believe I'm meeting you.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: No.  I expect you can't.

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: And this is your house.  Wow.  The house of Frankenstein.  I thought you'd live in a spooky old mansion or villa.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: One likes to live simply.

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: I know.  People's movies aren't their lives.

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: That's my favorite line in my favorite movie of yours.  "Bride of Frankenstein."

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Is it now?  Hanna?  I think we'll take our tea down by the swimming pool.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Will that be good for you, Mr. Kay?

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: After you then.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: This is the studio where I paint.

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: Nice.  And your lighting and camera angles.  You're got to go back to German silent movies to find anything like it.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: So, Mr. Kay?  What do you want to know?

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: Everything.  Start at the beginning.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: I was born outside London, the only son of a minister who was a master at Harrow.  Grandfather was a bishop.  Church of...Church of Eng...

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: Your father was a schoolmaster?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Of course.  I attended Eton -- it wouldn't do for a master's son to attend where his father taught.  I was to go up to Oxford but the war broke out and I never made it.  The Great War, you know.  You had a Good War, but we had a great one.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: There was one play in particular, a beautiful, grim study of war called "Journey's End".  Every experienced director turned it down, so I offered myself, bullying and begging for the job.  "Journey's End" made the careers of everyone associated with it.  It was only a matter of time until Hollywood beckoned.

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: How much longer before we get to "Frankenstein"?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Am I correct in assuming, Mr. Kay, that it's not me you're interested in, only my horror pictures?

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: Oh no, I want to hear everything. You made twenty pictures in all --

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Twenty-one.  The romantic comedies and dramas were much more to my liking.  The horror pictures were trifles.  Grand guignol for the masses.

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: But it's the horror movies you'll be remembered for.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: I am not dead yet, Mr. Kay.

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: No.  I never said you were.  Or will be soon.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: I have a proposal, Mr. Kay.  This mode of questioning is getting old, don't you think?

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: I don't mind.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Let's make it more interesting.  I will answer any question you ask. But, for each answer, you must remove one article of clothing.

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: That's funny, Mr. Whale.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: It is, isn't it?  My life as a game of strip poker.  Shall we play?

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: You're serious.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Quite.

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: Then the rumors are true?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: What rumors might those be?

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: That you were forced to retire because, uh -- a sex scandal.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: A homosexual scandal, you mean? For me to answer a question of that magnitude, you'll have to remove both your shoes and your socks.

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: Too warm for a sweater, anyway.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: You must understand how Hollywood was twenty years ago.  Nobody cared a tinker's cuss who slept with whom, so long as you kept it out of the papers.  Outside of Hollywood, who knows who George Cukor is, much less what he does with those boys from the malt shops along Santa Monica?

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: George Cukor?  Who made "A Star Is Born"?  I never guessed.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Take off your vest and I'll tell you a story.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Don't be shy.  There's time to stop before you go too far.

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: I guess.

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: Can we talk about the horror movies now?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Certainly, Mr. Kay.  Is there anything in particular you want to know?

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: Will you tell me everything you remember about making "Frankenstein"?

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: Can that count as one question?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Of course.

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: I can't believe I'm doing this.

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: Just like going swimming, isn't it?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Maybe you'd like a swim when we're through.  I never swim myself, so the pool tends to go to waste.

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: Okay.  "Frankenstein."  Tell me everything.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Righto.  Let me see.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Universal wanted me for another story, and wanted me so baldly -- I mean badly, not baldly.  I was given the pick of stories being developed, and I picked that one.

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: Who came up with the Monster's makeup and look?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: My idea.  Muchly.  My sketches. Big heavy brow.  Head flat on top so they could take out the old brain and put in the new, like tinned beef.

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: He's one of the great images of the twentieth century.  As important as the Mona Lisa.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: You think so?  That's very kind --

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: Mr. Whale?  Are you all right?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: I just need to -- lie down. Studio.  Daybed in studio.

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: Oh my God.  What's wrong, Mr. Whale?  Is it your heart?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Head.  Not heart.

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: I was going to take a swim.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: I'm sorry I spoiled it for you. You should probably go home.

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: Right.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Mr....Kay?

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: Bet you thought you'd never see me again.  I didn't know if you'd be well enough to come to this party.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: You didn't?

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: I'm the one who got you on Mr. Cukor's guest list.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: You, Mr. Kay?  How do you know George Cukor?

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: I interviewed him after I met you. I'm his social secretary now. Well, assistant to his secretary.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: I commend you.  If you're going to pursue poofs, go after those who can do favors for you.  You waste everybody's time when you court dinosaurs.

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: Don't think that, Mr. Whale.  I love your movies.  That's why I wanted you to come to this.  So I could see you with your monsters.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: My monsters?

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: Don't go away.

turns.speaker: PRINCESS MARGARET
turns.text: How are you?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Fine.  Quite fine.  And Your Royal Highness?

turns.speaker: PRINCESS MARGARET
turns.text: Splendid.  Now that I know you're around.

turns.speaker: PRINCESS MARGARET
turns.text: Can we get together while I'm in town?  I so badly want to sit for you again.

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Sit?

turns.speaker: PRINCESS MARGARET
turns.text: I've changed my hair, you see. Since our last session.  Those old snaps look rather dowdy now.

turns.speaker: PRINCESS MARGARET
turns.text: Oh dear.  Have I made a blunder?

turns.speaker: WHALE
turns.text: Ma'am, the pleasure is all mine.  James Whale.

turns.speaker: PRINCESS MARGARET
turns.text: I am such a goose.  I mistook you for Cecil Beaton.  It's the hat. You're wearing one of Cecil's hats, you know.

turns.speaker: MEMPHIS
turns.text: How's the leg?

turns.speaker: ATLEY JACKSON
turns.text: Only hurts when I breathe. Lookit you. Where are Barney Fife and Aunt Bea hanging out? And Opie ... Where's Opie at?

turns.speaker: MEMPHIS
turns.text: What are you doing here?

turns.speaker: ATLEY JACKSON
turns.text: Is there someplace we can talk?

turns.speaker: MEMPHIS
turns.text: What about?

turns.speaker: ATLEY JACKSON
turns.text: About your brother. And the deeeep shit he's in --

turns.speaker: ATLEY JACKSON
turns.text: It's been a long time, Memphis --

turns.speaker: MEMPHIS
turns.text: Six years ...

turns.speaker: ATLEY JACKSON
turns.text: Six years. Shit. Time flies, don't it? Six years ago we were fartin' through Armani and pissin' Cristal. Now look at us ...

turns.speaker: MEMPHIS
turns.text: Tell me about Kip -

turns.speaker: ATLEY JACKSON
turns.text: He took a job. And he fumbled it. Now he's jammed-up. Jammed-up bad...

turns.speaker: MEMPHIS
turns.text: What kind of job... ?

turns.speaker: ATLEY JACKSON
turns.text: A boost. A big boost ...

turns.speaker: MEMPHIS
turns.text: A boost? What's Kip doing on a boost?

turns.speaker: MEMPHIS
turns.text: It seems she neglected to mention it

turns.speaker: ATLEY JACKSON
turns.text: Maybe she don't know. Although I don't see how that could be. Maybe she didn't want to upset you -

turns.speaker: MEMPHIS
turns.text: Don't feel the need to explore my family dynamics, Atley...

turns.speaker: ATLEY JACKSON
turns.text: The point is: Kip's been living the life. Only he's a wild child. Crazy. Makes our old behavior seem like altar boy time. But he fungold this one so bad, folks around L.B. are already speakin' about him in the past tense.

turns.speaker: MEMPHIS
turns.text: Who was the job for?

turns.speaker: ATLEY JACKSON
turns.text: Who do you think?

turns.speaker: ATLEY JACKSON
turns.text: Car-jacker. Neglected to clean up after himself ...

turns.speaker: MEMPHIS
turns.text: Jesus ...

turns.speaker: ATLEY JACKSON
turns.text: The business has changed...

turns.speaker: MEMPHIS
turns.text: What's with the fish thing -- ?

turns.speaker: ATLEY JACKSON
turns.text: We can learn something from our Asian friends. They smoke a thousand cigarettes a day; they're completely stressed and overworked; they drink like, well ...

turns.speaker: MEMPHIS
turns.text: Fish.

turns.speaker: ATLEY JACKSON
turns.text: And they still have the lowest rate of cancer of anywhere in the world. You know why? All they eat is seafood.

turns.speaker: MEMPHIS
turns.text: Also, never underestimate the restorative powers of "Karaoke."

turns.speaker: ATLEY JACKSON
turns.text: I do a poaching number. Six-ounce fillets in a saucepan of brine. In 8 minutes, I could cater a goddamn wedding. Plain but flavorful. And it's a good way to show off my Hollandaise sauce ...

turns.speaker: MEMPHIS
turns.text: You have a Hollandaise sauce ?

turns.speaker: ATLEY JACKSON
turns.text: I do ...  Christ, what happened to us ?

turns.speaker: MEMPHIS
turns.text: Speak for yourself, boss I don't have a Hollandaise sauce

turns.speaker: ATLEY JACKSON
turns.text: No, but you dress like an asshole ...

turns.speaker: MEMPHIS
turns.text: I think about that night a lot...

turns.speaker: ATLEY JACKSON
turns.text: Me, too. Every time I walk...

turns.speaker: MEMPHIS
turns.text: How they were just there ... Waiting on us ... The fix was definitely in ...

turns.speaker: ATLEY JACKSON
turns.text: Yeah -- ?

turns.speaker: MEMPHIS
turns.text: Yeah Tell him to lay off Kip and them Tell him it's on

turns.speaker: ATLEY JACKSON
turns.text: Jesus, man ... What'd you do?

turns.speaker: MEMPHIS
turns.text: My version of "take this job and shove it..."

turns.speaker: ATLEY JACKSON
turns.text: Are you crazy? You throw down with The Carpenter? You got a grudge against your life?

turns.speaker: ATLEY JACKSON
turns.text: Ding Dong The Witch Is Dead, right?

turns.speaker: MEMPHIS
turns.text: Point-five ...
